div1.head: Pamphlet: Should the United States Correct This Ingratitude?, by the Chamber of Commerce, White Plains, N.Y., February 15, 1928
div1.p:
CHAMBER of COMMERCE
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y.
February 15th, 1928

SHOULD THE UNITED STATES CORRECT
THIS INGRATITUDE?

Congress this winter will be called upon to offer belated
justice to the group of American soldiers and medical
men who in 1900 offered their lives as the price of this
country's present immunity from yellow fever.

If the response to this call remains in doubt, it is only
because of the short memory of the public. Only two
decades or so ago the praises of this little =-
perimenters rang through the country, for one of the
most sensational as well as one of the most useful deeds
ever performed by man. Ironically enough, our indiffer-
ence to-day is due to the whole-heartedness of their sacri-
fice and the completeness of their triumph. Yellow fever
now is one of the mythical horrors of history, in the same
category as the “Black Death”; hence the younger gen-
eration cannot understand the emotion which swept our
country in 1901 when the story of the army experiments
in Cuba became known. There was nothing vague about
yellow fever then. Within the memory of many men
now living it was regarded as one of the most dreadful
of human scourges, but nevertheless an unavoidable men-
ace to life on the Gulf Coast and in the Carribbean. In
1878 an epidemic of this disease spread from the Gulf
ports even as far as Boston leaving a desolate waste of
death and financial ruin.

At the close of the Spanish American War, yellow fever
attacked the American troops then stationed near Havana
with such dreadful results that a popular saying gained
credence, that yellow fever killed more American boys
than had Spanish bullets. The army seemed helpless
against this new onslaught. The Cuban authorities had
been vainly fighting the disease for centuries and they
had no remedy to offer. Finally a commission was ap-
pointed consisting of Dr. Walter Reed, Dr. James Carrol,
Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, and Dr. Aristides Agramonte to
study the disease and see what could be done to check it.

The efforts of these men, and of the little group of
soldiers who volunteered to assist them, comprise a story
of deliberate heroism equal to any deed of bravery in the
annals of our nation; for much of the work involved
conscious exposure to yellow fever at a time when such
exposure almost inevitably meant death in a terrible form,
and these men knew it would be necessary for some of
them to catch the disease in order that its method of
transmission might be understood. There was evidence
that a certain species of mosquito was the only medium
through which yellow fever was spread. If this could be
proved, then the extermination of this mosquito would
check the disease.

In most instances, experiments upon animals under
scientific observation have enabled medical men to ac-
complish great cures or to devise methods of prevention
without exacting a high toll in human suffering and death.
But there were no animals known upon whom yellow
fever has the same effects as it has upon human beings.
These experiments, therefore, had to be made directly
upon men, and this with full knowledge of what it meant,
by the participants.

Dr. Reed explained this situation and called for volun-
teers to submit themselves to innoculation. The entire
commission insisted on volunteering though their leader
was himself prohibited from participating by Presidential
order. This was not unexpected, since medical men have
generally been willing to set the example by offering their
own lives under such conditions.

But when two private soldiers, John R. Kissinger and
John J. Morgan of Ohio, volunteered their services without
reward, Kissinger explaining that they were offering their
lives “solely in the interest of humanity and the cause of
science,” the Major saluted the two privates, saying later
in his report, “In my opinion this exhibition of moral
courage has never been surpassed in the annals of the
army of the United States.”

Kissinger submitted to the bite of an infected mosquito.
He was stricken with yellow fever in consequence, but
fortunately recovered. Several others followed his ex-
ample and most of them developed the disease, but medi-
cal attention saved their lives. But in previous cases this
ordeal had ended more seriously. Dr. Lazear had allowed
a suspected mosquito to bite him, and he paid for the
experiment with his life. Dr. Carroll had also developed
yellow fever in the same way, and recovered only after
a long illness.

Other phases of the experiment were attended with un-
speakable horror, even though they were not fatal. It
was necessary to prove beyond any doubt that yellow fever
could not be transmitted between human beings by either
direct or indirect contact. To establish this some of the
experimenters exposed themselves to infection in every
possible way, except through mosquito bite. Privates Jer-
negan and Folk and Dr. Cook, for one instance, stayed
for twenty days and nights in an unventilated, room,
sleeping on bedding and wearing clothing used by men
who had previously died of yellow fever. No infection
followed; and by this and similar experiments it was defin-
itely established that the mosquito was the sole carrier of
the disease. Later experiments led to the extermination
of these mosquitoes in fever infected zones, and the eradi-
cation of the yellow fever scourge promptly followed.

Among the material rewards that America received
from these men's work was the Panama Canal, the con-
struction of which had been declared impossible until the
yellow fever had been conquered; the rise of Havana as
a tourist resort which immediately followed the eradica-
tion of yellow fever in that city; and the extermination of
this disease and all it implies in the saving of men and
millions, throughout the cities of the South, and indeed
of the entire western hemisphere.

The reward of the men themselves? Piece-meal pen-
sions for a few, no money reward of any kind for the
others, wild public acclaim followed by forgetfulness for
them all. At first the survivors of the experiments were
more than willing that this should be so. They had
asked no reward for their work--money cannot pay for
loss of life or even of health--hence they had nothing
to ask of this country when they were being hailed as
heroes. Time went on and they were forgotten. Death
and disability overtook some of them, and their depend-
ents. But recently Mr. James E. Peabody of White
Plains, Instructor of Biology in Morris High School, New
York, became interested in their later history, through
his friendship with Private Kissinger. He has brought to
light facts which, with the help of the White Plains Cham-
ber of Commerce, he is making known to the nation;
facts that need only to be revealed in order to insure the
generosity and justice due the survivors by the American
people.

After he left the army, Private Kissinger became crip-
pled--whether this is an aftermath of his yellow fever ex-
perience will never be known--and for thirteen years was
unable to work. At present a small government pension
and the generosity of a few friends are keeping him from
absolute want, but his needs are not being adequately met;
certainly not in proportion to his generosity to the nation.

Private Jernegan is buried in Spartansburg, S. C., and
he leaves a widow whose claim upon a grateful nation's
generosity is manifest. He is entitled to burial in the
national cemetery at Arlington, but there are no govern-
ment funds available for transporting his body as his
widow wishes to have done.

Dr. Carroll died from heart failure a few years follow-
ing the experiments. Again there is a question of the ex-
tent to which his voluntary submission to yellow fever
infection was responsible for his death. There is no ques-
tion, however, that his widow is justly entitled to an ade-
quate pension in partial compensation for her husband's
sacrifice.

Mrs. Jesse Lazear, whose husband was the first martyr
to the yellow fever experiments, was left without adequate
resources by her husband's death, and the routine pension
allowd her is inadequate acknowledgement of our national
gratitude.

Dr. Walter Reed is also dead, leaving a widow who is
likewise entitled to our most generous recognition of her
husband's work in behalf of us all.

Only a direct pension bill providing specifically for each
case, can meet the needs of these survivors. So many
difficulties of pension classification, army rank, and appro-
priation red-tape in general, stand in the way of their
being cared for as a group. It has been proposed that a
permanent commission be appointed to take care of this
and similar government obligations in the future.

Meantime, a nation wide movement to acknowledge the
services of these men by a suitable pension is under way.
Congress will act if the people wish it to. Considering
the months of torture, and the gift of life and health that
these men made for our country, is it too much to ask
each reader of this statement to do one of three things at
once:
1. Write to your own Congressman calling attention to
this matter and urging action.
2. Show this statement to your neighbors or have it
read in your church, club, or community gathering,
asking all who hear it and sympathize with its pur-
pose to write their Congressman also.
3. Write to your local papers; use every other means
you have to get official action by Chambers of Com-
merce and other social and civic bodies, whose influ-
ence will incite Congress to action.
A Resolution to be Submitted to Congressional Vote

To recognize the eminent public service rendered by
the participants in the investigations conducted by Dr.
Walter Reed, U. S. A., and his associates which deter-
mined the methods of transmission of yellow fever; to
provide suitable annuities for all those, or their surviving
dependents, who voluntarily participated in those investi-
gations at the conscious risk of life and health; and to
establish a permanent method of national recognition and
reward for American citizens who have voluntarily jeopar-
dized their lives in scientific research for the public good,
or who may do so hereafter.

Whereas, the experiments made by Major Walter A.
Reed and his associates during an epidemic of yellow fever
which involved United States troops stationed in Cuba in
1900, resulted in the development of methods through
which this disease was afterwards eradicated in Cuba, in
Panama, and in other fever infected regions, to the ever-
lasting benefit of humanity; and

Whereas, to bring about this epochal result a number
of officers, enlisted men, and other American citizens,
voluntarily and with full knowledge of the danger in-
volved and with no other hope of reward than the con-
sciousness of performing a service to their country, risked
their lives and well-being by living in discomfort, priva-
tion, and danger in conditions then generally conducive to
yellow fever infection; and by exposing themselves to yel-
low fever infection from which some died and from which
others suffered long and painful illness; and

Whereas, although the service those investigators per-
formed for their country was clearly in excess of the du-
ties upon which their compensation was based and for
which the standard pension system provides, no corres-
ponding provision has ever been made by the Federal
Government in recognition of their extraordinary self-
sacrifice, with the result that many of them and their sur-
viving dependents have since suffered unmerited privation,
want, and in some cases destitution; and

Whereas, the public interest alone, regardless of the dic-
tates of generosity and gratitude for heroic public service
willingly performed, demands that such deeds be publicly
acknowledged and that citizens who in the future shall
offer their lives for the common good may feel that their
sacrifice will be requited with substantial evidence of the
nation's gratitude, that their dependents will be cared for,

Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa-
tives of the United States of America in Congress assem-
bled, that in special recognition of the high public ser-
vice rendered, suffering endured, and disabilities con-
tracted by them in the interest of humanity and science
as volunteer subjects for experimentation during the yel-
low fever investigations in Cuba, aforesaid, the Secretary
of War be, and he is hereby authorized and directed to
place on the roll of the War Department the names of
Major Walter Reed, Major James Carroll; Jesse W. Lazear,
Robert P. Cook, Aristides Agramonte, late contract sur-
geons, United States Army; John R. Kissinger, Lovi E.
Folk, Clyde L. West, James L. Hanberry, Charles G. Son-
tag, Warren Cadsen Jernegan, William Olsen, Wallace W.
Forbes, John H. Andrus, Edward Weatherwalk, James
Hildebrand, Thomas M. England, late of the Hospital
Corps, United States Army; William H. Dean, late of
Troop B. Seventh Cavalry, United States Army; Albert
W. Covington, Paul Hamann, late of Twenty-third Com-
pany, Coast Artillery, United States Army; John J.
Moran, late civilian clerk, United States Army; and John
R. Bullard, a volunteer; or the names of their widows, and
pay them for and during their natural life, in lieu of all
annuities which might have been heretofore granted or in
lieu of any pensions now received, the sum of ($ )
per month; and

Be it further enacted, that the President of the United
States be and is hereby empowered and directed to ap-
point a permanent commission to be known as the Na-
tional Honors Commission, the composition, powers, and
duties of which commission shall be determined within the
limits, and subject to the policies enumerated as follows:

(1) The commission shall consist of (seven) members
chosen from the following positions of public trust: (a
member of the staff of) the Surgeon General of the U. S.
Army, (a member of the staff of) the Surgeon General
of the U. S. Navy, (a member of the staff of) the Sur-
geon General of the U. S. Public Health Service, an ad-
ministrative official of the U. S. Bureau of Standards, an
administrative official of the Smithsonian Institute, (two)
presidents of American Colleges or Universities (disburs-
ing Federal funds under the Morrill Law of 1872).

(2) The commission shall investigate all cases of citi-
zens employed in any capacity in the public service of the
United States, who through the voluntary risk of life or
health, shall have made possible conspicuous contributions
to the wellbeing and happiness of the people of the coun-
try, and shall have endured serious disability or privation
thereby. The commission shall determine the amount and
nature of the recognition to which each such citizen is
justly entitled, which recognition may take the form of
money grants, or pensions, or annuities or medals, or me-
morials, or any other form warranted by the exigencies of
each individual case. The commission shall make a full
report to the President of all circumstances surrounding
each individual case and shall recommend suitable action
thereon.

(3) The commission shall be responsible only to the
President, and shall determine its own procedure, subject
to the President's approval. The commission shall serve
without compensation, but shall have requisite powers of
summoning witnesses of engaging necessary auxiliary ser-
vice, and of incurring such other expense as may be requi-
site to the thorough and prompt performance of its duties.

The President shall report to Congress the findings of
the commission, recommending such action as he deems
proper.

All acts embodied in those resolutions shall be in effect
immediately upon passage thereof.

(During the present session of Congress the provisions
of the above Bill will be introduced by Representative
Wainwright, New York, in the House of Representatives
and Senator Royal S. Copeland, New York, in the Sen-
ate.)
